the risk management plan is a component of the project management plan and describes how risk management . activity will be structured and performed. the risk management plan includes the following. •	 methodology. defines the approaches, tools, and data source that will be used to perform risk . management on the project •	 role and responsibilities. defines the lead, support, and risk management team member for each . type of activity in the risk management plan, and clarifies their responsibility •	 budgeting. estimate fund needed, based on assigned resources, for inclusion in the cost baseline and . establishes protocol for application of contingency and management reserve •	 timing. defines when and how often the risk management process will be performed throughout the . project life cycle, establishes protocol for application of schedule contingency reserves, and establishes . risk management activity for inclusion in the project schedule  . this copy is a pmi member benefit, not for distribution, sale, or reproduction . •	 risk categories. provide a mean for grouping potential cause of risk . several approach can be . used, for example, a structure based on project objective by category. a risk breakdown structure rb . help the project team to look at many source from which project risk may arise in a risk identification . exercise. different rb structure will be appropriate for different type of projects. an organization can . use a previously prepared custom categorization framework, which may take the form of a simple list of . category or may be structured into an rbs. the rb is a hierarchical representation of risk according . to their risk categories. an example is shown in figure beta distribution triangular distribution. . . . beta and triangular distribution are frequently used in quantitative risk analysis. the data shown in the figure . on the left beta distribution is one example of a family of such distribution determined by two shape . parameters. other commonly used distribution include the uniform, normal and lognormal. in these chart . the horizontal x ax represent possible value of time or cost and the vertical y ax represent relative . likelihood. . figure . example of a risk breakdown structure rbs. •	 definition of risk probability and impact. the quality and credibility of the risk analysis requires that . different level of risk probability and impact be defined that are specific to the project context. general . definition of probability level and impact level are tailored to the individual project during the plan . risk management process for use in subsequent processes. table is an example of definition of . negative impact that could be used in evaluating risk impact related to four project objectives. similar . table may be established with a positive impact perspective. table illustrates both relative and . numerical in this case, nonlinear approach  . this copy is a pmi member benefit, not for distribution, sale, or reproduction . table . definition of impact scale for four project objectives. defined condition for impact scale of a risk on major project objective . example are shown for negative impact only . relative or numerical scale are shown. project . very low . low . moderate . high . very high objective.  scope reduction project end item. scope decrease minor area of major area of. scope unacceptable to is effectively. barely noticeable scope affected scope affected. sponsor useless. only very demanding quality reduction quality reduction project end item . quality degradation. quality application requires sponsor unacceptable to is effectively. barely noticeable. are affected approval sponsor useless. this table present example of risk impact definition for four different project objectives. they should be tailored in the . risk management planning process to the individual project and to the organization risk thresholds. impact definition can be . developed for opportunity in a similar way •	 probability and impact matrix. a probability and impact matrix is a grid for mapping the probability . of each risk occurrence and it impact on project objective if that risk occurs. risk are prioritized . according to their potential implication for having an effect on the project’s objectives. a typical . approach to prioritizing risk is to use a lookup table or a probability and impact matrix. the specific . combination of probability and impact that lead to a risk being rated as “high,” “moderate,” or “low” . importance are usually set by the organization •	 revised stakeholders’ tolerances. stakeholders’ tolerances, as they apply to the specific project, may . be revised in the plan risk management process •	 reporting formats. reporting format define how the outcome of the risk management process will . be documented, analyzed, and communicated. it describes the content and format of the risk register as . well as any other risk report required •	 tracking. tracking document how risk activity will be recorded for the benefit of the current project . and how risk management process will be audited  . this copy is a pmi member benefit, not for distribution, sale, or reproduction

Definition: analytical technique are used to understand and define the overall risk management context of the project. . risk management context is a combination of stakeholder risk attitude and the strategic risk exposure of a given . . project based on the overall project context. for example, a stakeholder risk profile analysis may be performed to . grade and qualify the project stakeholder risk appetite and tolerance. other technique , such as the use of strategic . risk scoring sheets, are used to provide a highlevel assessment of the risk exposure of the project based on the . overall project context. depending on these assessments, the project team can allocate appropriate resource and . focus on the risk management activity

to ensure a comprehensive establishment of the risk management plan, judgment, and expertise should be . considered from group or individual with specialized training or knowledge on the subject area, such as •	 senior management ,. •	 project stakeholders,. •	 project manager who have worked on project in the same area directly or through lesson learned,. •	 subject matter expert smes in business or project area,. •	 industry group and consultants, and. •	 professional and technical association  . this copy is a pmi member benefit, not for distribution, sale, or reproduction .

project team hold planning meeting to develop the risk management plan. attendee at these meeting may . include the project manager, selected project team member and stakeholders, anyone in the organization with . responsibility to manage the risk planning and execution activities, and others, as needed highlevel plan for conducting the risk management activity are defined in these meetings. risk management . cost element and schedule activity should be developed for inclusion in the project budget and schedule, . respectively. risk contingency reserve application approach may be established or reviewed. risk management . responsibility should be assigned. general organizational template for risk category and definition of term . such as level of risk , probability by type of risk , impact by type of objectives, and the probability and impact matrix . will be tailored to the specific project. if template for other step in the process do not exist, they may be generated . in these meetings. the output of these activity are summarized in the risk management plan

project assumption are found in the project scope statement. uncertainty in . project assumption should be evaluated as potential cause of project risk the wbs is a critical input to identifying risk as it facilitates an understanding of the potential risk at both . the micro and macro levels. risk can be identified and subsequently tracked at summary, control account, andor . work package level

activity cost estimate review are useful in identifying risk as they provide a . quantitative assessment of the likely cost to complete scheduled activity and ideally are expressed as a range, . with the width of the range indicating the degree of risk . the review may result in projection indicating the . estimate is either sufficient or insufficient to complete the activity i.e., pose a risk to the project

the primary output from identify risk is the initial entry into the risk register. the risk register is a document . in which the result of risk analysis and risk response planning are recorded. it contains the outcome of the other . risk management process as they are conducted, resulting in an increase in the level and type of information . contained in the risk register over time. the preparation of the risk register begin in the identify risk process . . with the following information, and then becomes available to other project management and risk management . processes. •	 list of identified risk . the identified risk are described in as much detail as is reasonable. a . structure for describing risk using risk statement may be applied, for example, event may occur . causing impact, or if cause exists, event may occur leading to effect. in addition to the list of . identified risk , the root cause of those risk may become more evident. these are the fundamental . condition or event that may give rise to one or more identified risk . they should be recorded and . used to support future risk identification for this and other project •	 list of potential responses. potential response to a risk may sometimes be identified during the identify . risk process. these responses, if identified in this process, should be used as input to the plan risk . response process  . this copy is a pmi member benefit, not for distribution, sale, or reproduction
Synonyms: ['risk objective', 'risk risk', 'risk characteristic', 'risk threshold', 'risk audit', 'risk impact', 'risk interview', 'risk attitude', 'risk term', 'risk description', 'risk test', 'risk tool', 'risk event', 'risk driver', 'risk response']

Definition: a structured review of the project documentation may be performed, including plans, assumptions, previous . project files, agreements, and other information. the quality of the plans, as well as consistency between those . plan and the project requirement and assumptions, may be indicator of risk in the project

Definition: example of information gathering technique used in identifying risk can include. •	 brainstorming. the goal of brainstorming is to obtain a comprehensive list of project risk . the project . team usually performs brainstorming, often with a multidisciplinary set of expert who are not part of the . team. idea about project risk are generated under the leadership of a facilitator, either in a traditional . freeform brainstorm session or structured mass interviewing technique . category of risk , such as in a . risk breakdown structure, can be used as a framework. risk are then identified and categorized by type . of risk and their definition are refined •	 delphi technique. the delphi technique is a way to reach a consensus of experts. project risk expert . participate in this technique anonymously. a facilitator us a questionnaire to solicit idea about the . important project risk . the response are summarized and are then recirculated to the expert for . further comment. consensus may be reached in a few round of this process. the delphi technique help . reduce bias in the data and keep any one person from having undue influence on the outcome  . this copy is a pmi member benefit, not for distribution, sale, or reproduction . •	 interviewing. interviewing experienced project participants, stakeholders, and subject matter expert . help to identify risk •	 root cause analysis. rootcause analysis is a specific technique used to identify a problem, discover . the underlying cause that lead to it, and develop preventive action
Synonyms: ['data gathering proficiency', 'data gathering technique', 'data assembly proficiency', 'data gather proficiency', 'information potential risk', 'data assembly technique']

Definition: risk identification checklist are developed based on historical information and knowledge that ha been . accumulated from previous similar project and from other source of information. the lowest level of the rb . can also be used as a risk checklist. while a checklist may be quick and simple, it is impossible to build an . exhaustive one, and care should be taken to ensure the checklist is not used to avoid the effort of proper risk . identification. the team should also explore item that do not appear on the checklist. additionally, the checklist . should be pruned from time to time to remove or archive related items. the checklist should be reviewed during . project closure to incorporate new lesson learned and improve it for use on future project

. every project and it plan is conceived and developed based on a set of hypotheses, scenarios, or assumptions. . assumption analysis explores the validity of assumption as they apply to the project. it identifies risk to the . project from inaccuracy, instability, inconsistency, or incompleteness of assumption

risk diagramming technique may include. •	 cause and effect diagrams. these are also known as ishikawa or fishbone diagram and are useful for . identifying cause of risk •	 system or process flow charts. these show how various element of a system interrelate and the . mechanism of causation •	 influence diagrams. these are graphical representation of situation showing causal influences, time . ordering of events, and other relationship among variable and outcomes, as shown in figure  . this copy is a pmi member benefit, not for distribution, sale, or reproduction . project risk . estimate condition. project. deliverables. activity. figure . influence diagram.

this technique examines the project from each of the strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, and threat swot . perspective to increase the breadth of identified risk by including internally generated risk . the technique start . with identification of strength and weakness of the organization, focusing on either the project, organization, . or the business area in general. swot analysis then identifies any opportunity for the project that arise from . organizational strengths, and any threat arising from organizational weaknesses. the analysis also examines . the degree to which organizational strength offset threats, as well as identifying opportunity that may serve to . overcome weakness  . this copy is a pmi member benefit, not for distribution, sale, or reproduction .

risk may be identified directly by expert with relevant experience with similar project or business areas. . such expert should be identified by the project manager and invited to consider all aspect of the project and . suggest possible risk based on their previous experience and area of expertise. the experts’ bias should be taken . into account in this process

key element of the risk management plan used in the perform qualitative risk . analysis process include role and responsibility for conducting risk management , budgets, schedule activity . for risk management , risk categories, definition of probability and impact, the probability and impact matrix, . and revised stakeholders’ risk tolerances. these input are usually tailored to the project during the plan risk . management process. if they are not available, they may be developed during the perform qualitative risk analysis . process

Definition: risk probability assessment investigates the likelihood that each specific risk will occur. risk impact . assessment investigates the potential effect on a project objective such as schedule, cost, quality, or performance, . including both negative effect for threat and positive effect for opportunity probability and impact are assessed for each identified risk . risk can be assessed in interview or meeting . with participant selected for their familiarity with the risk category on the agenda. project team member and . knowledgeable person external to the project are included the level of probability for each risk and it impact on each objective is evaluated during the interview or meeting. . explanatory detail, including assumption justifying the level assigned, are also recorded. risk probability . and impact are rated according to the definition given in the risk management plan. risk with low rating of . probability and impact will be included within the risk register as part of the watch list for future monitoring  . this copy is a pmi member benefit, not for distribution, sale, or reproduction .

risk data quality assessment is a technique to evaluate the degree to which the data about risk is useful . for risk management . it involves examining the degree to which the risk is understood and the accuracy, quality, . reliability, and integrity of the data about the risk the use of lowquality risk data may lead to a qualitative risk analysis of little use to the project. if data quality is . unacceptable, it may be necessary to gather better data. often, the collection of information about risk is difficult, . and consumes more time and resource than originally planned. the value used in the example in figure . are representative. the number of step in the scale are usually established when defining the risk attitude of the . organization

project document are updated with information resulting from quantitative risk analysis. for example, risk . register update could include. •	 probabilistic analysis of the project. estimate are made of potential project schedule and cost . outcome listing the possible completion date and cost with their associated confidence levels. . this output, often expressed as a cumulative frequency distribution, is used with stakeholder risk . tolerance to permit quantification of the cost and time contingency reserves. such contingency . reserve are needed to bring the risk of overrunning stated project objective to a level acceptable to . the organization •	 probability of achieving cost and time objectives. with the risk facing the project, the probability . of achieving project objective under the current plan can be estimate d using quantitative risk analysis . results. for instance, in figure , the likelihood of achieving the cost estimate of u million is . about •	 prioritized list of quantified risk . this list includes those risk that pose the greatest threat or present . the greatest opportunity to the project. these include the risk that may have the greatest effect on cost . contingency and those that are most likely to influence the critical path. these risk may be evaluated, in . some cases, through a tornado diagram generated as a result of the simulation analysis •	 trend in quantitative risk analysis results. as the analysis is repeated, a trend may become apparent . that lead to conclusion affecting risk responses. organizational historical information on project schedule, . cost, quality, and performance should reflect new insight gained through the perform quantitative risk . analysis process. such history may take the form of a quantitative risk analysis report. this report may . be separate from, or linked to, the risk register  . this copy is a pmi member benefit, not for distribution, sale, or reproduction

Definition: •	 interviewing. interviewing technique draw on experience and historical data to quantify the probability . and impact of risk on project objectives. the information needed depends upon the type of probability . distribution that will be used. for instance, information would be gathered on the optimistic low, . pessimistic high, and most likely scenario for some commonly used distributions. example of three. point estimate for cost are shown in figure . additional information on threepoint estimate . appears in estimate activity duration section . and estimate cost section documenting the . rationale of the risk range and the assumption behind them are important component of the risk . interview because they can provide insight on the reliability and credibility of the analysis range of project cost estimate . wbs element low most likely high. design m m m. build m m m. test m m m. total project m m m. interviewing relevant stakeholder help determine the threepoint estimate for each wbs. element for triangular, beta or other distributions. in this example, the likelihood of completing. the project at or below the most likely estimate of million is relatively small as shown in . the simulation result in figure cost risk simulation result figure . range of project cost estimate collected during the risk interview.  . this copy is a pmi member benefit, not for distribution, sale, or reproduction . •	 probability distributions. continuous probability distributions, which are used extensively in modeling . and simulation, represent the uncertainty in value such as duration of schedule activity and cost . of project components. discrete distribution can be used to represent uncertain events, such as the . outcome of a test or a possible scenario in a decision tree. two example of widely used continuous . distribution are shown in figure . these distribution depict shape that are compatible with the . data typically developed during the quantitative risk analysis. uniform distribution can be used if there . is no obvious value that is more likely than any other between specified high and low bounds, such as in . the early concept commonly used technique use both eventoriented and projectoriented analysis approaches, including. •	 sensitivity analysis. sensitivity analysis help to determine which risk have the most potential . impact on the project. it help to understand how the variation in project’s objective correlate with . variation in different uncertainties. conversely, it examines the extent to which the uncertainty of . each project element affect the objective being studied when all other uncertain element are held at . their baseline values. one typical display of sensitivity analysis is the tornado diagram figure , . which is useful for comparing relative importance and impact of variable that have a high degree of . uncertainty to those that are more stable. the tornado diagram is also helpful in analyzing risk taking . scenario enabled on specific risk whose quantitative analysis highlight possible benefit greater . than corresponding identified negative impacts. a tornado diagram is a special type of bar chart used . in sensitivity analysis for comparing the relative importance of the variables. in a tornado diagram, . the yaxis contains each type of uncertainty at base values, and the xaxis contains the spread or . correlation of the uncertainty to the studied output. in this figure, each uncertainty contains a horizontal . bar and is ordered vertically to show uncertainty with a decreasing spread from the base value risk . risk . risk . risk . key negative impact. risk positive impact. risk . , , , , , , ,. figure . example of tornado diagram.  . this copy is a pmi member benefit, not for distribution, sale, or reproduction . •	 expected monetary value analysis. expected monetary value emv analysis is a statistical concept . that calculates the average outcome when the future includes scenario that may or may not happen . i.e., analysis under uncertainty. the emv of opportunity are generally expressed as positive values, . while those of threat are expressed as negative values. emv requires a risk neutral assumption—. neither risk averse nor risk seeking. emv for a project is calculated by multiplying the value of each . possible outcome by it probability of occurrence and adding the product together. a common use of . this type of analysis is a decision tree analysis figure decision definition decision node chance node net path value. input scenario probability, . input cost of each decision computed . decision to reward if it occurs. output decision made payoff minus cost . be made output expected monetary . along path. value emv . strong demand m. m. m m – m. build new plant. invest m. m . m weak demand m. . –m m . emv before cost of build –m m – m. build or upgrade? new plant considering demand . decision emv m strong demand. the larger of m m. m. and m. m m – m. upgrade plant. invest m. decision node. chance node m mm weak demmand m. end of branch emv before cost of upgrade m m – m. plant considering demand . note the decision tree show how to make a decision between alternative capital strategy represented as “decision . nodes” when the environment contains uncertain element represented as “chance nodes” note here, a decision is being made whether to invest m u to build a new plant or to instead invest only m us. to upgrade the existing plant. for each decision, the demand which is uncertain, and therefore represents a. “chance node” must be accounted for. for example, strong demand lead to m revenue with the new plant. but only m u for the upgraded plant, perhaps due to capacity limitation of the upgraded plant. the end of. each branch show the net effect of the payoff minus costs. for each decision branch, all effect are added see. shaded area to determine the overall expected monetary value emv of the decision. remember to account for. the investment costs. from the calculation in the shaded areas, the upgraded plant ha a higher emv of m – . also the emv of the overall decision. this choice also represents the lowest risk , avoiding the worst case possible . outcome of a loss of m figure . decision tree diagram.  . this copy is a pmi member benefit, not for distribution, sale, or reproduction . •	 modeling and simulation. a project simulation us a model that translates the specified detailed . uncertainty of the project into their potential impact on project objectives. simulation are typically . performed using the monte carlo technique. in a simulation, the project model is computed many time . iterated, with the input value e.g., cost estimate or activity duration chosen at random for each . iteration from the probability distribution of these variables. a histogram e.g., total cost or completion . date is calculated from the iterations. for a cost risk analysis, a simulation us cost estimate . for a . schedule risk analysis, the schedule network diagram and duration estimate are used. the output from a . cost risk simulation using the threeelement model and risk range is shown in figure . it illustrates . the respective probability of achieving specific cost targets. similar curve can be developed for other . project objective total project cost. cumulative chart. . mean .m. . y. bilit. a . b. o. pr. . . . m m. .m .m .m .m .m. cost. this cumulative distribution, assuming the data range in figure and triangular distributions, show that the . project is only percent likely to meet the million most likely cost estimate . if a conservative organization want . a likelihood of success, a budget of million a contingency of nearly m mm is required figure . cost risk simulation results.  . this copy is a pmi member benefit, not for distribution, sale, or reproduction .

expert judgment ideally using expert with relevant, recent experience is required to identify potential cost . and schedule impacts, to evaluate probability, and to define input such as probability distribution into the tool expert judgment also come into play in the interpretation of the data. expert should be able to identify the . weakness of the tool as well as their strengths. expert may determine when a specific tool may or may not be . more appropriate given the organization’s capability and culture

important component of the risk management plan include role and responsibilities, risk analysis definitions, . . timing for review and for eliminating risk from review, and risk threshold for low, moderate, and high risk . risk . threshold help identify those risk for which specific response are needed
Synonyms: ['risk management action', 'risk management design', 'risk response plan', 'risk management resource', 'risk management procedure', 'risk analysis example', 'risk management rule']

Definition: the risk register refers to identified risk , root cause of risk , list of potential responses, risk owners, symptom . and warning signs, the relative rating or priority list of project risk , risk requiring response in the near term, risk . for additional analysis and response, trend in qualitative analysis results, and a watch list, which is a list of low. priority risk within the risk register
Synonyms: ['risk objective', 'risk risk', 'risk characteristic', 'risk threshold', 'risk audit', 'risk impact', 'risk interview', 'risk attitude', 'risk term', 'risk description', 'risk test', 'risk tool', 'risk event', 'risk driver', 'risk response']

Definition: element of the project management plan that may be updated as a result of carrying out this process include, . but are not limited to.  . this copy is a pmi member benefit, not for distribution, sale, or reproduction . •	 schedule management plan. the schedule management plan is updated to reflect change in process . and practice driven by the risk responses. this may include change in tolerance or behavior related to . resource loading and leveling, as well as update to the schedule strategy •	 cost management plan. the cost management plan is updated to reflect change in process and . practice driven by the risk responses. this may include change in tolerance or behavior related to . cost accounting, tracking, and reports, as well as update to the budget strategy and how contingency . reserve are consumed •	 quality management plan. the quality management plan is updated to reflect change in process . and practice driven by the risk responses. this may include change in tolerance or behavior related to . requirements, quality assurance, or quality control, as well as update to the requirement documentation •	 procurement management plan. the procurement management plan may be updated to reflect . change in strategy, such as alteration in the makeorbuy decision or contract type driven by the risk . response •	 human resource management plan. the staffing management plan, part of the human resource . management plan, is updated to reflect change in project organizational structure and resource . . application driven by the risk responses. this may include change in tolerance or behavior related to . staff allocation, as well as update to the resource loading •	 scope baseline. because of new, modified or omitted work generated by the risk responses, the scope . baseline may be updated to reflect those change •	 schedule baseline. because of new work or omitted work generated by the risk responses, the schedule . baseline may be updated to reflect those change •	 cost baseline. because of new work or omitted work generated by the risk responses, the cost baseline . may be updated to reflect those change

in the plan risk response process, several project document are updated as needed. for example, when . appropriate risk response are chosen and agreed upon, they are included in the risk register. the risk register . should be written to a level of detail that corresponds with the priority ranking and the planned response. often, the . high and moderate risk are addressed in detail. risk judged to be of low priority are included in a watch list for . periodic monitoring. update to the risk register can include, but are not limited to.  . this copy is a pmi member benefit, not for distribution, sale, or reproduction . •	 risk owner and assigned responsibilities. •	 agreedupon response strategies. •	 specific action to implement the chosen response strategy. •	 trigger conditions, symptoms, and warning sign of a risk occurrence. •	 budget and schedule activity required to implement the chosen responses. •	 contingency plan and trigger that call for their execution. •	 fallback plan for use as a reaction to a risk that ha occurred and the primary response prof to be . inadequate. •	 residual risk that are expected to remain after planned response have been taken, as well as those that . have been deliberately accepted. •	 secondary risk that arise as a direct outcome of implementing a risk response and. •	 contingency reserve that are calculated based on the quantitative risk analysis of the project and the . organization’s risk threshold other project document updated could include. •	 assumption log updates. as new information becomes available through the application of risk . responses, assumption could change. the assumption log need to be revisited to accommodate this . new information •	 technical documentation updates. as new information becomes available through the application . of risk responses, technical approach and physical deliverable may change. any supporting . documentation need to be revisited to accommodate this new information •	 change requests. planning for possible risk response can often result in recommendation for change . to the resources, activities, cost estimate , and other item identified during other planning processes. . when such recommendation are identified, change request are generated and processed through the . perform integrated change control process  . this copy is a pmi member benefit, not for distribution, sale, or reproduction
Synonyms: ['undertaking document update', 'project team stakeholder', 'project team member', 'project management tool', 'project contingency fund', 'project risk output', 'project completion date', 'project management rule', 'project management discipline', 'project management method']

Definition: three strategies, which typically deal with threat or risk that may have negative impact on project objective . if they occur, are avoid, transfer, and mitigate. the fourth strategy, accept, can be used for negative risk or threat . as well as positive risk or opportunities. each of these risk response strategy have varied and unique influence . on the risk condition. these strategy should be chosen to match the risk ’s probability and impact on the project’s . overall objectives. avoidance and mitigation strategy are usually good strategy for critical risk with high impact, . while transference and acceptance are usually good strategy for threat that are le critical and with low overall . impact. the four strategy for dealing with negative risk or threat are further described as follows. •	 avoid. risk avoidance is a risk response strategy whereby the project team act to eliminate the threat or . protect the project from it impact. it usually involves changing the project management plan to eliminate . the threat entirely. the project manager may also isolate the project objective from the risk ’s impact or . change the objective that is in jeopardy. example of this include extending the schedule, changing the . strategy, or reducing scope. the most radical avoidance strategy is to shut down the project entirely. . some risk that arise early in the project can be avoided by clarifying requirements, obtaining information, . improving communication, or acquiring expertise •	 transfer. risk transference is a risk response strategy whereby the project team shift the impact of . a threat to a third party, together with ownership of the response. transferring the risk simply give . another party responsibility for it management —it doe not eliminate it. transferring doe not mean . disowning the risk by transferring it to a later project or another person without his or her knowledge or . agreement. risk transference nearly always involves payment of a risk premium to the party taking on . the risk . transferring liability for risk is most effective in dealing with financial risk exposure. transference . tool can be quite diverse and include, but are not limited to, the use of insurance, performance bonds, . warranties, guarantees, etc. contract or agreement may be used to transfer liability for specified risk . to another party. for example, when a buyer ha capability that the seller doe not possess, it may be . prudent to transfer some work and it concurrent risk contractually back to the buyer. in many cases, use . of a costplus contract may transfer the cost risk to the buyer, while a fixedprice contract may transfer . risk to the seller  . this copy is a pmi member benefit, not for distribution, sale, or reproduction . •	 mitigate. risk mitigation is a risk response strategy whereby the project team act to reduce the . probability of occurrence or impact of a risk . it implies a reduction in the probability andor impact of an . adverse risk to be within acceptable threshold limits. taking early action to reduce the probability andor . impact of a risk occurring on the project is often more effective than trying to repair the damage after the . risk ha occurred. adopting le complex processes, conducting more tests, or choosing a more stable . supplier are example of mitigation actions. mitigation may require prototype development to reduce the . risk of scaling up from a benchscale model of a process or product. where it is not possible to reduce . probability, a mitigation response might address the risk impact by targeting linkage that determine the . severity. for example, designing redundancy into a system may reduce the impact from a failure of the . original component •	 accept. risk acceptance is a risk response strategy whereby the project team decides to acknowledge . the risk and not take any action unless the risk occurs. this strategy is adopted where it is not possible . or costeffective to address a specific risk in any other way. this strategy indicates that the project . team ha decided not to change the project management plan to deal with a risk , or is unable to identify . any other suitable response strategy. this strategy can be either passive or active. passive acceptance . requires no action except to document the strategy, leaving the project team to deal with the risk as . . they occur, and to periodically review the threat to ensure that it doe not change significantly. the . most common active acceptance strategy is to establish a contingency reserve, including amount of . time, money, or resource to handle the risk

three of the four response are suggested to deal with risk with potentially positive impact on project objectives. . the fourth strategy, accept, can be used for negative risk or threat as well as positive risk or opportunities. these . strategies, described below, are to exploit, share, enhance, and accept •	 exploit. the exploit strategy may be selected for risk with positive impact where the organization wish . to ensure that the opportunity is realized. this strategy seek to eliminate the uncertainty associated with . a particular upside risk by ensuring the opportunity definitely happens. example of directly exploiting . response include assigning an organization’s most talented resource to the project to reduce the time . to completion or using new technology or technology upgrade to reduce cost and duration required to . realize project objective  . this copy is a pmi member benefit, not for distribution, sale, or reproduction . •	 enhance. the enhance strategy is used to increase the probability andor the positive impact of an . opportunity. identifying and maximizing key driver of these positiveimpact risk may increase the . probability of their occurrence. example of enhancing opportunity include adding more resource to . an activity to finish early •	 share. sharing a positive risk involves allocating some or all of the ownership of the opportunity to a . third party who is best able to capture the opportunity for the benefit of the project. example of sharing . action include forming risk sharing partnerships, teams, specialpurpose companies, or joint ventures, . which can be established with the express purpose of taking advantage of the opportunity so that all . party gain from their action •	 accept. accepting an opportunity is being willing to take advantage of the opportunity if it arises, but . not actively pursuing it

some response are designed for use only if certain event occur. for some risk , it is appropriate for . the project team to make a response plan that will only be executed under certain predefined conditions, if . it is believed that there will be sufficient warning to implement the plan. event that trigger the contingency . response, such as missing intermediate milestone or gaining higher priority with a supplier, should be defined . and tracked. risk response identified using this technique are often called contingency plan or fallback plan . and include identified triggering event that set the plan in effect
Synonyms: ['contingent reaction scheme', 'contingent response scheme', 'contingent reply scheme', 'contingent answer strategy', 'contingent answer scheme', 'contingent reception scheme', 'contingent reaction strategy', 'contingency reserve level', 'contingent reception strategy']

the project management plan, which includes the risk management plan, provides . guidance for risk monitoring and controlling

implementing contingency plan or workarounds sometimes result in a change request. change request are . prepared and submitted to the perform integrated change control process section change request can . include recommended corrective and preventive action as well •	 recommended corrective actions. these are activity that realign the performance of the project . work with the project management plan. they include contingency plan and workarounds. the latter . are response that were not initially planned, but are required to deal with emerging risk that were . previously unidentified or accepted passively. . •	 recommended preventive actions. these are activity that ensure that future performance of the . project work is aligned with the project management plan

if the approved change request have an effect on the risk management processes, the corresponding component . document of the project management plan are revised and reissued to reflect the approved changes. the element . of the project management plan that may be updated are the same as those in the plan risk response process  . this copy is a pmi member benefit, not for distribution, sale, or reproduction . . project document updates. project document that may be updated as a result of the control risk process include, but are not limited to the . risk register. risk register update may include. •	 outcome of risk reassessments, risk audits, and periodic risk reviews. these outcome may . include identification of new risk , update to probability, impact, priority, response plans, ownership, and . other element of the risk register. outcome can also include closing risk that are no longer applicable . and releasing their associated reserve •	 actual outcome of the project’s risk and of the risk responses. this information can help project . manager to plan for risk throughout their organizations, as well as on future projects. . . organizational process asset updates. the risk management process produce information that may be used for future projects, and should be . captured in the organizational process assets. the organizational process asset that may be updated include, but . are not limited to. •	 template for the risk management plan, including the probability and impact matrix and risk register,. •	 risk breakdown structure, and. •	 lesson learned from the project risk management activity these document should be updated as needed and at project closure. final version of the risk register and the . risk management plan templates, checklists, and risk breakdown structure are included  . this copy is a pmi member benefit, not for distribution, sale, or reproduction.

Definition: risk audit examine and document the effectiveness of risk response in dealing with identified risk and their . root causes, as well as the effectiveness of the risk management process. the project manager is responsible for . ensuring that risk audit are performed at an appropriate frequency, as defined in the project’s risk management . plan. risk audit may be included during routine project review meetings, or the team may choose to hold separate . risk audit meetings. the format for the audit and it objective should be clearly defined before the audit is conducted  . this copy is a pmi member benefit, not for distribution, sale, or reproduction .

Definition: many control process employ variance analysis to compare the planned result to the actual results. for the . purpose of controlling risk , trend in the project’s execution should be reviewed using performance information. . earned value analysis and other method of project variance and trend analysis may be used for monitoring overall . project performance. outcome from these analysis may forecast potential deviation of the project at completion . from cost and schedule targets. deviation from the baseline plan may indicate the potential impact of threat or . opportunity

many control process employ variance analysis to compare the planned result to the actual results. for the . purpose of controlling risk , trend in the project’s execution should be reviewed using performance information. . earned value analysis and other method of project variance and trend analysis may be used for monitoring overall . project performance. outcome from these analysis may forecast potential deviation of the project at completion . from cost and schedule targets. deviation from the baseline plan may indicate the potential impact of threat or . opportunity

technical performance measurement compare technical accomplishment during project execution to the . schedule of technical achievement. it requires the definition of objective, quantifiable measure of technical . performance, which can be used to compare actual result against targets. such technical performance measure . may include weight, transaction times, number of delivered defects, storage capacity, etc. deviation, such as . demonstrating more or le functionality than planned at a milestone, can help to forecast the degree of success . in achieving the project’s scope

throughout execution of the project, some risk may occur with positive or negative impact on budget or . schedule contingency reserves. reserve analysis compare the amount of the contingency reserve remaining to . the amount of risk remaining at any time in the project in order to determine if the remaining reserve is adequate

project risk management should be an agenda item at periodic status meetings. the amount of time required . for that item will vary, depending upon the risk that have been identified, their priority, and difficulty of response. . the more often risk management is practiced, the easier it becomes. frequent discussion about risk make it more . likely that people will identify risk and opportunity  . this copy is a pmi member benefit, not for distribution, sale, or reproduction .

plan risk management is the process of defining how to conduct risk management activity for a project. the . key benefit of this process is it ensures that the degree, type, and visibility of risk management are commensurate . with both the risk and the importance of the project to the organization. the risk management plan is vital to . communicate with and obtain agreement and support from all stakeholder to ensure the risk management process . is supported and performed effectively over the project life cycle.

identify risk is the process of determining which risk may affect the project and documenting their . characteristics. the key benefit of this process is the documentation of existing risk and the knowledge and ability . it provides to the project team to anticipate events.

perform qualitative risk analysis is the process of prioritizing risk for further analysis or action by assessing . and combining their probability of occurrence and impact. the key benefit of this process is that it enables project . manager to reduce the level of uncertainty and to focus on highpriority risk .

perform quantitative risk analysis is the process of numerically analyzing the effect of identified risk on overall . project objectives. the key benefit of this process is that it produce quantitative risk information to support decision . making in order to reduce project uncertainty.

plan risk response is the process of developing option and action to enhance opportunity and to reduce . threat to project objectives. the key benefit of this process is that it address the risk by their priority, inserting . resource and activity into the budget, schedule and project management plan as needed.
Synonyms: ['plan risk reaction', 'plan hazard response', 'plan hazard answer', 'plan hazard reception', 'plan risk answer', 'plan risk reception', 'plan risk reply', 'plan hazard reaction', 'risk response plan']

Definition: control risk is the process of implementing risk response plans, tracking identified risk , monitoring residual . risk , identifying new risk , and evaluating risk process effectiveness throughout the project. the key benefit of . this process is that it improves efficiency of the risk approach throughout the project life cycle to continuously . optimize risk responses.
